text.text: The symbiotic relationship between light competition and drinking is one of the great harmonies in life and excellent lubrication for gearing into a catch up at the pub. There’s only so many times you can ask about someone’s job and how their mum is doing before you have to start getting inventive with your conversation topics. But inject some friendly antagonism and you’ll unlock an unlimited supply of dynamic back-and-forth for you and your drinking partner - these are some of our favourite pubs for games.

tip.text:
Skehans is a proper family boozer, small in size but large in stature. Here regular live music, pool, darts, footie, old blokes necking Guinness and arty moochers from Goldsmith’s fill the space and create one of the best pub atmospheres in town. It's a unique mishmash melting pot and the result is goddamn good craic.

Set up in an old Victorian corner pub, it’s got the look and feel you want from your local; where, as things get wild after dark, you get the sense the night could go anywhere. Meanwhile, out back is a rare unexpected gem: a leafy garden with a converted coach house doing very tasty Thai food to complete this perfect pub package.

text.text: This old Victorian free house has most things you could ask for from a boozer - a nice garden, live music, good food, plus it's family run but with a slight edge of rowdiness come evening time. As for activities we're talking pool, darts, board games, and the once ubiquitous and now nearly extinct fruit machine - when were all the fruities replaced with small plates?

tip.text:
The Montague Arms used to be a bit of an institution, much loved by locals for its punk gigs and rowdy queer nights. Like many a London pub, it's now been sanitised, toned down to appeal to the latest type of Peckham coloniser.

It may not be as much of a joyride anymore, but at least a link with Bethnal Green's Satan's Whiskers promises some tidy cocktails. Together they've worked up a menu of classics - white russians, old fashioneds, negronis and the like, and some less classic boozy slushies for the weekend. Other tricks up this pub's sleeve include arcade games, table football, board games and a weird thing called shuffleboard along with palm trees, bougie chairs and the type of ceiling fans you'd only expect to find in the tropics.

text.text: A proud member of the New Ownership Survivors Guild, The Monty has been given a bit of a facelift whereby the punky roughness has been replaced with something more kitsch. And we're OK with it - especially considering the vast array of games they've added, from pinball and arcade machines to table football, board games and shuffleboard (like curling for old people that aren't Canadian).

tip.text: This bohemian boozer in Shoreditch has one of our favourite beer gardens in London. It's a huge area with plenty of space to sit, lit by fairy lights and an ideal spot to enjoy one of their craft beers or grill-inspired menu. There's also a pool parlour, screens to catch some sport and loads of rooms ideal for birthdays or private hire.

text.text: Most people know The Water Poet for its giant (for Shoreditch) outdoor area - a fairy-lit courtyard of bohemia - but a lesser known treasure is the pool room. With dark-wood flooring, gold accents and low lights, you almost long for a Mad Men-esque smokey haze to add to the aesthetic. You can reserve one of the tables and the other is saved for walks-ins, which seems perfectly fair to us.

tip.text:
There are plenty of shitty drinking holes to find yourself in near King's Cross but The Queen's Head is not one of them. This is an intimate, bustling Victorian joint which keeps things simple: 'the way it used to be', we imagine someone might say. Though not us, we don't really know how things used to be.

There's a big selection of beers and ales, with three real ale pumps and craft specialities from across the globe. The atmosphere is also nice and jovial - there's no music unless the piano in the corner gets some action or they've got one of their jazz nights on. You can also have a go at dominoes or backgammon if that's your game.

text.text: This drinking hole keeps things simple - and not in a stripped-back scandi-chic way, but more of a 'how things used to be' way. That means old-school decor, a nice range of ales, and some games of the classic variety. We’re talking backgammon, dominoes and chequers. Sitting here in King's Cross surrounded by the clack of counters, you can really start to channel that Victorian London worker aesthetic you've been working on since you finished Peaky Blinders.

tip.text:
The Red Lion is a cracking boozer, filled with a cross section of the community and all different ages. It had us falling in love with pub culture all over again. Chew the ear off a hardened regular and you’ll likely hear tales of The Rolling Stones or Led Zeppelin playing the upstairs ballroom. But screw the past, there’s still plenty goings on these days to keep us curious.

By day freelancers and young mums gather on sofas and in nooks. But by night the pub fills with punters turning up for one of the events. From free cinema and quizzes to garage and northern soul nights, this lot have your monthly calendar sorted. They even have an all day hip hop festival in the summer - where local artists graffiti the walls anew each year. Good British grub, board games, bloody marys, table football, kids' dance classes... it's less of a pub and more the heart of Leytonstone.

text.text: This Leytonstone institution is a gargantuan jack of all trades that actually manages to master a fair few of them. It's usually filled with a cross-section of the community and has enough varied activities to keep them all entertained: food, booze, gigs, festivals, free film screenings and classes. On the game front, you're looking at table football, an arcade machine and board games. If you get bored here, that's on you.

tip.text: A place to get your game face on and feel right at home. Modelled on Tokyo's gamer cafes, this is a place to 'drink, relax and play'. Dojo likes doing all of that, but we've never tried them all at once. There are board games, retro arcade games and collaborative spaces where you can play on their consoles with other gamer sorts. Their drinks list is also game-inspired with 'World of Barcraft' and 'Rum Total War' among the strong bevvies on offer.

text.text: A table-top gaming pub upstairs and and a video game cavern in the basement - this feels like the kinda place the kids from Stranger Things would hang out if they were British and old enough to drink. There are dozens of table-top (that's nerd for board) games to play for free, from Monopoly all the way to more obscure classics like Cosmic Encounter. Downstairs they have both classic and modern games consoles so you can crush your pal at whatever version of Mario Kart was popular when you were a kid.

tip.text: A city pub through and though, The Bell’s Aldgate postcode means it pulls in a more office-y crowd than we’d like - but come outside of the post-work-pint hours and you’ll find a perfectly charming spot for a drink. While the beers are pretty standard, the rough wood panelling, eclectic furniture and some odd artwork give you plenty to look at. Also there’s a sweet basement games room with pool and table football for competitive types.

text.text: A city pub through and though, The Bell’s Aldgate postcode means it pulls in a more office-y crowd than we’d like - but come outside of the post-work-pint hours and you’ll find a perfectly charming spot for a drink. While the beers are pretty standard, the rough wood panelling, eclectic furniture and some odd artwork give you plenty to look at. And there’s a sweet basement games room with pool and table football for you to prove your worth.

tip.text:
Make it out to this Thames-side pub in Hammersmith and you might just think you've fallen asleep on the bus and found yourself in Oxfordshire. A three-storey white-washed cottage overlooking the river, with benches spilling out front and a nice floral garden behind - this feels like a country pub through and through.

Food is of the modern gastro variety - with a fair few vegan options - and drinks are the expected pints alongside some decent cocktails. But it's in the activities department where the Black Lion truly shines: they've got a vintage skittles alley (one of the few in London), plus darts and ping pong in the garden - nothing like a bit of friendly competition for you to prove how much better you are than your drinking partner.

text.text: Make it out to this Thames-side pub in Hammersmith and you might just think you've fallen asleep on the bus and found yourself in Oxfordshire. Overlooking the river, it's got a real country-pub vibe, but it's in the activities department where the Black Lion truly shines: they've got darts and ping pong tables outside, plus a proper vintage skittles alley - one of the last in London, don't cha know.

tip.text:
This place is so much more than a pub. All ales served at The Four Thieves are brewed in-house, literally - the brewery is slap bang on the ground floor, just sat right there. The Boat House next door is a separate comedy venue complete with a ship bar. An actual ship. Oh, and there’s also a gin garden (the back bar is stocked with 70+ gins).

That’s all downstairs. Upstairs, the enormous arcade is the stuff of dreams. We’re talking ping-pong tables and retro pinball machines. The best bit comes courtesy of the Racing Bug residency: scaled up Scalextric = Formula fun. Weekly antics include comedy nights, bottomless brunch on the weekend and resident eccentric Boogaloo Stu’s Dirty Bingo (not for the faint-hearted).

text.text: The pinnacle of a pub with games: a sprawling maze of rooms that range from conservatories, to dance floors, to drinking dens, to regular pub lounges. Head upstairs and you’ll find the playground of your eight-year-old self's dreams with retro arcade machines, mini golf, virtual reality, an immersive escape room, and - overlooking everything in all its glory - an eight player RC-car race track! Damn, even our eight-year-old selves lacked that much imagination.
